author: Harper Lee
review: A powerful portrayal of racial injustice and moral growth in the American South.

author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
review: A dazzling portrait of the Roaring Twenties and the American Dream.

author: George Orwell
review: A haunting vision of a dystopian society where truth is manipulated and individuality suppressed.

author: J.D. Salinger
review: A poignant coming-of-age story that explores themes of alienation and identity.

author: Suzanne Collins
review: A gripping tale of survival and rebellion in a dystopian future.

bookName: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone
author: J.K. Rowling
review: An enchanting tale of magic, friendship, and adventure.

author: Gillian Flynn
review: A twisty and unsettling psychological thriller that keeps you guessing until the very end.

bookName: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo
author: Stieg Larsson
review: An electrifying mystery thriller with complex characters and a gripping plot.

author: Jahanara Imam
review: In the last two days, I opened 3-4 books and read them a little bit. If you read a book in your own language, you may find a different peace. It liquidated me inside. It is the most detailed of all the contemporary memoirs I have read in the 1970s. Akhtaruzzaman Ilyas wrote in his diary about the mass uprising of 69 but did not add anything about 71. Sufia Kamal's diary was not as big in length as this one but good. Humayun Ahmed and Zafar Iqbal's memoirs about their father and 71, the part written by Humayun Ahmed, as always, was an attempt to create a feeling in his writing. Jahanara Imam's writing focuses on many areas.
